Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the father should provide guidance
Situation2: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, watching my son push his vegetables around his plate, his lips pressed into a stubborn line. I knew I should be patient, guiding him gently, teaching him the importance of healthy habits and respect for the food we have. But my phone buzzed again—another message from the hospital. My patient, Mrs. Lee, was having a flare-up. Her autoimmune disease was unpredictable, and she needed me to review her labs and adjust her medications immediately. I could hear the urgency in the nurse’s voice from the last call. My son looked up at me, waiting for my attention, expecting me to help him understand why manners matter. At the same time, I felt the weight of my responsibility as a doctor—someone’s health depended on my expertise and swift action. My heart pulled in two directions, torn between being the father my son needed in this moment and the doctor my patient depended on. I stared at my phone, then at my son, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in, unsure which role to answer first.
